Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Future Woodland Composition in a Changing Climate: Abiotic and Biotic Controls on Tree Regeneration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Around the world, woody species are experiencing extensive mortality due to drought and insect outbreaks brought on by warmer temperatures. This has already altered the structure of forests and woodlands and affected fluxes of water and energy, carbon stocks, and ecosystem services. This project will evaluate the effects of climate on the woodlands of piñon pine and juniper trees that cover much of the southwestern U.S. Previous, intensive work on the ability of new trees to establish themselves from seeds in one locality will be combined with data on woodland composition, soils, and local climate across the region and analyzed to discover relationships between climate and forest regeneration. This will help predict how the vegetation of the southwest may shift with future change in climate, and advance our general understanding of how changes on a global scale affect local ecological systems.

The societal impacts of this study include increasing collaborations between university scientists and land managers, mentoring K-12 and undergraduate students, and incorporating the research into teaching. The study will enable land managers to identify areas that are most vulnerable to changes in piñon-juniper woodland structure and composition. Researchers will work with K-12 schools to teach students about the scientific process, mentor undergraduate students on independent research projects, and incorporate results into a module for an undergraduate course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Globally, woody species are experiencing extensive mortality due to drought, insect-outbreaks, and warmer temperatures. These mortality events have dramatically altered forest and woodland structure, affecting water and energy fluxes, carbon stocks, and ecosystem services. However, long-term changes in these wooded ecosystems will be dependent upon the ability of species to regenerate following these mortality events under a warmer, drier climate. This project examined the effects of climate and recent tree mortality on tree regeneration dynamics in the spatially extensive piñon–juniper woodland vegetation type of the southwestern USA. Piñon-juniper woodlands experienced severe piñon pine mortality due to a multi-year drought accompanied by warmer temperatures between 2002 and 2004, raising concern of whether these woodlands will be able to recover.   These woodlands provide essential ecosystem services, such as pine-nuts for commercial and non-commercial pine nut harvesters, and critical habitat for a wide range of wildlife species. Through field surveys conducted in piñon-juniper woodlands, this project examined whether these woodlands will be able to regenerate after the severe mortality event and under what conditions regeneration was most likely to occur.

Our findings suggest limited recovery of piñon pine populations on average across our study area, suggesting that these woodlands will become more juniper dominated in the future. However, some sites did have sufficient piñon pine regeneration. We identified three key criteria that can be used to assess the likelihood that a given area will have sufficient piñon pine regeneration: (1) sufficient canopy cover of overstory trees and shrubs to promote piñon juvenile survival; (2) sufficient seed source from surviving piñon pine trees with high reproductive output; (3) cooler and wetter local climate conditions and soil with a greater water holding capacity. In the absence of these conditions, there is a greater likelihood that these woodlands will transition to more xeric vegetation types.

This project provided research experience for four undergraduate students, three of whom did independent research projects on topics related to the effects of increasing water deficits and recent piñon mortality on woodland vegetation. In addition, this project has enhanced undergraduate education through the development of curriculum based on best teaching practices using the results from this study.
